newsitem.title: UK: Sweden best of a sorry bond lot this week -Salomon.
newsitem.headline: Sweden best of a sorry bond lot this week -Salomon.

text.p: Swedish bonds were the best performers in a week in which most government bonds crumbled under a catalogue of woes, according to data from Salomon Brothers on Friday.

Comments from Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan about the speculative nature of market rallies sent bonds tumbling last Friday. The sell-off continued this week amid talk the Japanese would begin to stop buying U.S. Treasuries.
Benign U.S. inflation data on Wednesday and Thursday helped stem losses but the overall Salomon Brothers World Government Bond Index ended up 0.50 percent in the red in local terms.
In U.S. dollar terms, the index was off 0.33 percent.

The only bond markets to end in the black in local terms were Sweden with a 0.21 percent gain and Canada ending 0.01 percent ahead. In U.S. dollar terms Sweden was 0.23 percent ahead and Canada 0.12 percent.
Spain and Switzerland ended flat in the week in local terms and ahead 0.53 percent and 0.29 percent respectively in dollars.
Finland was next in line registering a 0.21 percent loss in local terms, followed by Denmark with a 0.22 percent decline, Germany with a 0.24 percent drop and Belgium off 0.32 percent.

Other European countries dipped further, with the Netherlands down half a point in the week, Italy contracting 0.56 percent, France off 0.58 percent and British gilts, also pounded by political concerns, slumped 0.61 percent.
Treasuries were down 0.59 percent in the week, and Australian bonds off 0.36 percent. Japanese government bonds lost 0.67 percent in yen and a chunky 1.39 percent in dollar terms.
In dollar terms, the big winner was gilts, ahead 1.27 percent.

Salomon's bond index is calculated using all government bonds with over one year to maturity, weighted for market capitalisation. Only bonds freely available to institutional investors and with a certain minimum amount outstanding are included. Returns take account of price moves and accrued interest.
